title: So why don't riot just shut down script sites?
body:
botoflegends has been up for almost 3 years now.

Come on Riot, Stop this shit at the source.

replies.body: One way to stop those injecting scripters, is to build into the client some way to check for the exact script code that is on these types of websites, and then put all of the scripters into an elo limbo queue where they only play each other. Kinda like hellbanning. Quick, efficient, and without much hard work for Riot.

> [{quoted}](name=Cakemeisting,realm=OCE,application-id=Ntey9fRZ,discussion-id=g3qMcpQq,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2016-11-09T12:38:34.769+0000)
>
> One way to stop those injecting scripters, is to build into the client some way to check for the exact script code that is on these types of websites, and then put all of the scripters into an elo limbo queue where they only play each other. Kinda like hellbanning. Quick, efficient, and without much hard work for Riot.

Won't work. If it did, there'd be no scripters.
Do you have inside information that Riot have already tried this approach?

I suspect the reason they are left up is exactly that they can get hold of the bots, check them out, develop the countermeasures and when they've got a solid detect, employ a banwave.  They don't talk about this stuff, because you'd be like a jungler announcing what lane you were going to gank next.
Why hasn't piratebay been shut down yet with so many people trying to do so? Unfortunately it's not quite so simple.

on the other hand simply just checking these websites for how the scripts work and then creating specific countermeasures would probably be quite effective, since to function (especially on the alpha client) these scripts basically need an exploit to work and patching the exploit would mean that the creator of the scripting program would need to find new exploits. The issue with scripts is basically just riot putting effort into other things and turning a blind eye, rather than trying to get into a war to deal with scripters. Time spent countering scripters is time not spent dealing with bugs, competitive balance issues, the more controversial elements of the game and such.

> The issue with scripts is basically just riot putting effort into other things and turning a blind eye, rather than trying to get into a war to deal with scripters.

Thing is, they are basically in a war with scripters, that's why the ban waves are so large, and why we always see posts popping up on boards from people who swear they haven't used scripts (but usually shared their account with someone who did) and have gotten banned for it.

The scripts ARE constantly evolving and so are Riot's countermeasures. It's like Anti-virus vs Virus, they both have to be constantly evolving to try and stay one step ahead of the other, it's not a static solution but rather a dynamic one.

> Time spent countering scripters is time not spent dealing with bugs, competitive balance issues, the more controversial elements of the game and such.

The thing you seem to be misunderstanding is that Riot isn't one big team. The art teams are separate from the dev teams who are separate from the community teams who are separate from the balance teams who are separate from the champion design teams and so on. Time spent countering scripters does not affect time spent on anything else in the slightest.

> The scripts ARE constantly evolving and so are Riot's countermeasures. It's like Anti-virus vs Virus, they both have to be constantly evolving to try and stay one step ahead of the other, it's not a static solution but rather a dynamic one.

Difference is, when dealing with virus, suspecting, identifying, decryption and finding the exploit the virus is using is most of the time spent, whereas on these websites the scripts are up for show. With antivirus, you can't just go to google, the top viruses whereas the most common scripts are in the first few google scripts.
That said I acknowledge the issues with trying to stay up to date on these considering the sparsity of patches and also identifying accounts that have been using such programs, especially since antivirus primarily needs to focus on security, whereas riot has to primarily focus on the ongoing development of their game.

> The thing you seem to be misunderstanding is that Riot isn't one big team. The art teams are separate from the dev teams who are separate from the community teams who are separate from the balance teams who are separate from the champion design teams and so on. Time spent countering scripters does not affect time spent on anything else in the slightest.

Yeah but you still have to allocate technical staff and resources to the department in charge of managing scripts and cheating, I'm just saying it looks like riot has moved alot more of it's focus on the other teams since scripting is a problem that isn't soon going away.

Scripting is one of those problems like boosting, it's a problem that can be managed but it's not going away completely anytime soon unfortunately. As long as there is a market there will be a product.

I can't entirely disagree with you on this one, but speaking from my experience I'd say scripting is managed pretty well, and have yet to see anything that would tell me otherwise, but I'm one person playing in one level of play so it's not exactly the best sample size.
Takes too much time and effort, cost money and generally the site would come back under a different domain and owner.
